response.answer_text: The way I see it, it really depends on your determination. No one can tell you if you should or not. It’s up to you, and whether you can handle the burdens (including heartbreaks) that come with entering the kpop industry. And I will tell you now, the kpop industry is brutal. I will tell you straight from the shoulder, with no sugarcoated words or uphemisms that you have a very slim chance of making it. Especially in the big 3 (Jyp, YG, or SM). Koreans, non korean asians, and even half Koreans themselves already have a small chance of making it in even the smaller entertainments. Imagine how it will be like for someone with no asian descent? Yes, unfortunately race matters. It’s called Korean pop for a reason right? (I know Korean is not a race) And I am not at all trying to imply that people with no korean or any other type of asian descent cannot be beautiful. It’s just that Korean standards are harsh. As well as talent, entertainments also look at your physical appearance. If you do not have “Korean” or “asian” physical features, or if they find you unattractive then you will most likely not be accepted. I know it’s blunt, but it is reality. Now to give you a little bit of hope: There have been previous foreign, non asian kpop idols that have debuted in the past but sadly, did not make it very far (I know not very encouraging) but it doesn’t have to be this way for you! Like I said, it takes determination! You never know how things will turn out so don’t give up on your dreams right away when people try to bring you down (including me). Always jump for that opportunity because if things do not work out, at least you know you tried. Good luck and I hope you reach your dreams.

It's difficult to say, at this point. The K-pop industry is beginning to debut more half-Koreans and Asians from different countries. Slowly, but surely, diversity will be the main selling point for K-pop. Have we seen any progress for non-Asians? Hardly. We all know what happened to Alex, an African-American, from BP Rania. She became a part of the changed lineup in 2015, performing with the group as a member until 2017. However, she was constantly excluded from group activities and content. The company cited “issues with her visa” as a reason for her absences. Unfortunately, these absences were so frequent and scandalous, Alex left the group and returned home to the United States. She has since been releasing content as a solo artist. Will non-Asians have more chances to shine in five years? Ten years? Twenty? Maybe. But chances are very slim for them. You have to remember that South Korea is a conservative country. As representatives of the general public, they are the first to know about K-pop group lineups or new members. They may or may not perceive foreigners positively. Racism and discrimination against other races and ethnicities in the K-pop industry is not uncommon. Whether you agree with this or not, I have to say it. Most people (those internationally) listen to K-pop because they expect Asian singers and performers. Non-Asians don't cross their mind. If they did, they would be thinking about EXP Edition, an all-American “K-pop group” who doesn't have a single Asian member. Were they able to perform on Korean music shows? Yes, absolutely. Were they fully accepted by the general public? Er… not really. When you see and listen to that group, how does it make you feel? Does it help you envision a bright future for non-Asians in K-pop? For many, the future looks bleak for them. People have denounced EXP Edition from the K-pop industry, saying they don't “belong” in K-pop. “Asians can't succeed in the American industry, so why allow white/non-Asian Americans to become a K-pop group?” These are what non-Asians will continue to read if they were ever to debut today. The dialogue on this matter may change in the future, but I don't think it would mean accepting foreigners in an Asian entertainment industry. It's a divisive issue, after all. There's not exactly a conclusive answer to this question.

I am Chinese and I have nothing against non-Asians becoming K-pop idols. There have been so many non-Asians (at least half) joining the industry in recent years that I have honestly become quite used to it. I have also never really thought much about it when I first heard of Vernon from Seventeen (2014/2015) until it became such a big topic in 2020 (mostly because of KAACHI and LANA). I’ve seen some people referring this “issue” as cultural appropriation but I DISAGREE. Hear me out, not everything you do that’s not of your original culture is cultural appropriation. I think this word is too frequently misused especially in the entertainment industry. A non-Asian wanting to become a K-pop idol is not appropriating. It is similar to how Asians are striving in the Western music industry (look at 88rising), these performers just want to expand their artistry in a different part of the world. It is a dream, an experience. There is nothing wrong with it. If foreigners are accepted by companies and are given training just like any idol out there regardless of race and nationality, there is nothing wrong with these foreigners debuting in the K-pop industry. In the future when more representatives debut, it will become more normalized and I hope that will happen ASAP because this shouldn’t be an issue in the first place. (HEADS UP TO THOSE FAKE TRAINEES OUT THERE) On the other hand, if you are not properly trained like everyone else with the same dream and CLAIM to be a K-pop idol/trainee, this is appropriation, because you’re claiming a title that you have not worked hard for. These people have just disregarded ALL the training , ALL the blood, sweat and tears trainees have to go through to become an idol. THESE PEOPLE should stop and start educating themselves. I know cultural appropriation isn’t really part of the question but I just had to get it off my chest. I may not be completely correct so if anyone has anything to add or disagrees with me, feel free to comment and we can discuss and learn from one another. Be respectful (:

Here’s my two cents from another thread. Xintien Pei's answer to Is it possible for me to become a K-pop idol even if I'm a Hispanic? That would be almost impossible, unfortunately. The K-POP industry is quite homogeneous. As an idol, you have to be atleast partially of Korean/East Asian descent to debut. The trend among the few mixed idols also seemed to be half-caucasian half-asian e.g. SEVENTEEN’s Vernon, I.O.I’s Jeon So-mi. The whole ethically Korean/East Asian thing is also true for K-POP idols who weren’t even born or raised in an Asian country. Think of GOT7’s Mark and f(x)’s Amber, I doubt that they would have debuted as an idol if they were entirely of another race. Yeah I know, the whole process sounds racist. But the concept behind this is actually standard across all entertainment industries. The main goal of any business is profit - so What’s the best way an entertainment can appeal to its customers? The answer will probably be finding someone the target group can relate to. And, considering that the entertainment business is heavily dependent on visuals, the easiet way to achieve that would be to match the audience’s physicality, since that’s what most people notice first. K-POP has long since been marketed as having a korean-ish image. The industry also mainly promotes in Asia. These conditions unfortunately limit prospective idols into a very homogenous group. Even Hollywood displays a toned-down version of these racial-selective bias. Don’t believe me? Ok. Just think of how many caucasian hollywood stars you know. Now, try comparing that to the number of well-known African-Americans/Latinos/Asians in the industry. Add that to the fact that America is generally a racially-diverse nation, in oppose to Korean’s culture that is considerably more singular. One could easily see why there is virtually zero non-asians in the K-POP industry.  TL;DR. As of 2016, there is little chance that a non Korean-ish person would succeed in the k-pop industry. Though I think that you could still become a singer in Korean, just not in the traditional ‘idol’ sense. Footnote: Wow, this turned out longer than I expected. Sorry for any grammatical mistakes, I’m not a native speaker. Edits and comments would be much appreciated.

The easy answer is not really? Anything is possible and there have been a very VERY few select non-Asian individuals who have debuted as Kpop idols. But the more complicated answer is yes, you have to be at least half East Asian and look it on order to be an idol. Keep in mind, these companies are trying to form K-pop groups, as in KOREAN pop groups and looking the part is just as important as performing the music. Korea in general isn’t very fond of foreigners coming in and essentially “taking jobs” from netizens. It was only about 15 years ago when the first foreign Kpop idol debuted, Super Junior’s Hangeng and for awhile, he had to perform on stage with a mask to conceal the fact he wasn’t korean. Nowadays, companies have started debuting groups with foreign members as a marketing tactic to make global outreach easier and further. But that has mostly been exclusive to foreign members of East Asian Descent particularly Chinese, Japanese, and Thai. There are a few idols who are half Asian like Seventeen’s Vernon, Samuel, Momoland’s Nancy, and Jeon Somi, but they are half Korean and have Asian features so they don’t stick out too much. Anyways, while there are no specific rules saying you have to be Asian to become a trainee, most of the time, companies seem to only select East Asians to become trainees. Especially the larger companies since they all seem to have a specific “look/vibe” they go for. Sometimes a smaller lesser known company may take in non Asians because they’re desperate enough and having a non Asian May bring attention to the group. Like I said earlier, out of the hundreds of groups of idols, there have only been a select few non Asians who’ve made it to debut. The most prominent example would be Rania’s Alex. She had a small music career going in the US when DR music basically recruited her to be a new member of the group. They essentially used her as a prop to bring attention to this failing group and it kinda worked for a little bit. The members of Rania were good to her and they got along fine, the company on the other hand, treated her like crap. They left her out of a lot of promotions, giving excuses like “another schedule opportunity” even though we never saw her do anything. They left her out of the first music video she recorded music for. When they did allow her to perform with the group, most of the time, they’d have her walk out on stage, rap her part, then walk off or stand in the corner. There was only 1 comeback when they actually included her in the choreography. Eventually, the company decided they couldn’t use her anymore and just kick her out of the group. She didn’t ask to leave or anything, they just made an announcement saying Alex wasn’t part of the group anymore. Aside from her there was a Russian girl Sophia in the group Oh My Jewel and a French girl Olivia in The Gloss, neither group lasted more than a few months before disbanding. So to wrap things up, technically no, you don’t have to be asian to be a Kpop star, but your chances are very very very very slim. You’ll probably have a better shot at becoming the leader of your country than a Kpop Star if you’re not East Asian.

I see so many questions about non-Koreans becoming KPop stars. I see the superficial allure, but anyone who really drills down on the industry would likely be dissuaded. The process of “becoming a KPop Star” is not just a matter of showing up and passing a lucky audition and skyrocketing your way superstardom and vast wealth. As a child, you need to have talent. You need to take specific types of classes from specific instructors, and IF YOU’RE GOOD at this point, you MIGHT get signed to an agency. So at this point you’re into your tween-aged years, LIVING IN SEOUL, taking dance and voice lessons, getting your teeth and nose and chin and whatever fixed, and your agency is sending you to auditions at the entertainment companies. Listen to the stories of Hwasa and Weein of Mamamoo when they talk about taking the train into the city to go to auditions. Trying to keep their school work up. Trying to keep their agency, parents, teachers, and each other happy in the process. It’s BRUTAL. Companies will flat tell you every day that you’re too fat, too “tan”, your eyes need fixed, you sound like an angry cat and dance like a clumsy cow. Then you take the train back home, and hope you hear from the agency for another audition tomorrow. Oh, and this isn’t Mr JYP giving you fatherly advice BTW - these are choreographer’s assistant’s interns or some other total flunky who has life and death power over your career. IF you somehow become the first KPop Idol from Bedfordshire or Kentucky or Carabobo - that’s after passing at least one of those auditions, spending years in exhaustive training with the company, and enjoying the very rare event of a successful debut. If things are going “OK”, you’re making $20,000 to $60,000 per year - as much as if you’d started out at McDonald’s, and worked your way up to store manager (NOT THAT THERE’S ANYTHING WRONG WITH THAT). You've got 10–15 years invested into a career, at the expense of everything else, and you’re now semi-famous in an industry few can remain successful or even popular in for as long as 10 years. Yes, of course there are KPop millionaires. But dig into the stories of Hyuna, the girls from Twice, or your favorite idols. It’s a long hard road to get there. Ask yourself whatever happened to… the girls from Icia, the girls from D-holic, 2 of the 6 girls from Dalshabet… the myriads of those who “almost” made it. (watch the TV show “The Uni+” to hear some of the stories) NOW, ASK YOURSELF THIS: If you truly believe that you are TALENTED enough to be in your favorite KPop group - WHY NOT sing and dance and “be an idol” right where you are? If you have a great voice, use it where you are. the whole world loves music, it’s everywhere - and watching pretty people dance is probably not going away. Self production has made it simple to produce studio-quality music anywhere with a laptop. the internet allows you to collaborate worldwide. Need some beats? Jump on craigslist and buy some. Everything you need is either at your fingertips, or within your own means of production. [1 in every 8 Americans is making music in some way] I would argue that you’re more likely to be successful, or at least make a living, or a profitable hobby with your music in your own country than somewhere else. Superstardom is a tough ask anywhere in the world - why make it harder by moving to another country when you’re 11?

Short answer: yes, though there may be some issues and obstacles. Long answer: it’s possible, but it will be really hard. A big “decision-maker” would be whether you speak Korean or not. If you don’t, it will be even harder to make it than if you do. Also if you do make it and you don’t know Korean, you will have to take classes to learn it, and that can be difficult for some. Another issue would be whether you fit Korean beauty standards. I’m not going to go into the nitty-gritty, but they tend to like a more “innocent” looking face, which is also a reason why haters like to say the boys look like girls- because they kinda do. The biggest issue you will ever face,though, will be the extreme training and nearly overloaded schedules. If you think you might get even the slightest bit homesick if you don’t get to talk to your family often, and by often I mean once a week, then I wouldn’t even try. You will be miles away and won’t have much time to see or talk to your family AT ALL. You also will be pushed to and past your limit during training, and if you aren’t thé desired weight when they weigh you(and they will), you may be put on a diet, and those can sometimes be dangerous to your health. And lastly, being a trainee is EXPENSIVE. Once you’re in Korea, you will have to usually pay for food, clothing, and sometimes even housing, and none of those are going to be cheap. You won’t be getting paid by the company you’re in for these either, which makes things worse. So if even after reading all this, you still want to go through with trying to be a non-Asian kpop idol, by all means, do it. But if any of what I just told you are things you wouldn’t want to do, you might want to rethink your decision.

As a Korean I really laugh a lot at the non-Korean Kpop fans who try to gate-keep the racial stock of idols in the Kpop industry. One thing that frustrates me is that non-Korean Kpop fans seem to think that all Mongoloid/Indo-European East/SE Asia have some sort of collective ownership and credit to the Korean music industry and popular culture. To us Koreans, idols like Momo (Japanese), Lisa (Thai), Tzuyu (Taiwanese), Sorn (Thai), Sana (Japanese), Cheng Xiao (Mainland Chinese), etc. are just as foreign as Lana (Russian).  Lana who was a Russian trainee debuted and created quite some controversy. While I agree with the controversy regarding poor quality control and obvious accusations of white privilege, I disagree with the buzz around her for being a “culture vulture” and how non-Asians can’t rightfully be in Kpop.  Meanwhile Lisa (a Thai idol) is an extremely popular idol outside of Korea (particularly in Thailand and the West) and has never faced such backlash or controversy. If Kpop fans aren’t willing to accept foreigners in Kpop, they should at least be consistent in their xenophobia. If you want to preserve Kpop’s immaculate ethnic stock so much then disparage idols like Momo, Sana, Lisa, Tzuyu, Cheng Xiao, Lay, etc. the same way you do for KAACHI and Lana. This type of double standard ties back to a racist sentiment pervasive in the West that really bothers me: that is, the generalization of Asia. Most Westerners seem to think that East/SE Asia is some type of big happy family with a shared common culture and ethnic stock. In reality, we all have incredibly strong national identities and all have our own respective cultures and histories. Hence, Lana being an idol makes me feel the same type of way in which Momo is an idol: nothing. However, one important thing I should point out is that when I refer to “Western” ignorance, I am not referring to a certain racial group. Instead, I’m blaming pretty much anyone outside of Asia of this sort of ignorance. I never understood why or how one could find the motivation to uphold another ethnic group’s achievement as if it were your own. For example, if Japan’s football team were to win the World Cup, I wouldn’t be jumping up and down thinking that this is some collective victory for the “Asians;” instead, I’d see it as a victory achieved by the country of Japan and nothing else. Not only is this over-generalization of Asian cultures and histories annoying but it has actual consequences. Racial policy in the US towards Asians have long been targeting East Asians (Chinese, Japanese, Koreans); as a result, Southeast Asians have experienced increased marginalization and exclusion from the political narrative. Hence for the Kpop fans who think white or black (non-Asian) idols have a lesser right to be in the industry than forsay a Japanese or Thai, I’d like to tell you to first off, erase your double standards, and secondly, educate yourself on basic geography.
